sect1.title: CASE 2
sect1.para: The patient was a 21-year-old male presenting to the emergency department (ED) with 2 days of yellow penile discharge. He denied dysuria, flank pain, hematuria, and scrotal or testicular swelling and refused a genitourinary exam. His physical exam was otherwise unremarkable, and he was not ill-appearing.

listitem.para: 1. What are the most likely causes of this patient’s presentation?
2. What diagnostic testing should be obtained?

sect1.para: Urine was collected for Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, and Trichomonas vaginalis nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs). A fourth-generation antigen/antibody HIV screen and rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test for syphilis were also ordered. The patient was ready to be discharged from the ED prior to results being available.

listitem.para: 3. How should the patient be treated?

sect1.para: The patient received intramuscular (IM) ceftriaxone and was prescribed 7 days of doxycycline. The urine NAATs were positive for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis and negative for T. vaginalis. The HIV screen and RPR were also negative.

A month later, he returned to the ED with about a week of penile discharge. He acknowledged that he completed his prior antibiotic regimen and that the initial symptoms had resolved. He denied any new sexual partners. An N. gonorrhoeae NAAT from urine was positive. C. trachomatis and T. vaginalis NAATs from urine, fourth-generation antigen/antibody HIV screen, and RPR were all negative.

listitem.para: 4. What are the possible explanations for the patient’s repeat positive N. gonorrhoeae NAAT?
5. How long does N. gonorrhoeae DNA remain after treatment, and what is the recommended interval between testing by NAAT?

sect1.para: He was treated again with IM ceftriaxone. As all test results were not available at the time of discharge, the patient was also given 1 week of doxycycline as empiric therapy for C. trachomatis.

Two months later, the patient returned to the ED for a third time, again with penile discharge for 1 week. Similar to the prior visit, he acknowledged that he completed his prior antibiotic regimen and that the initial symptoms had resolved. However, given the repeated bouts of urethritis, treatment failure was given greater consideration.

listitem.para: 6. What additional testing should be performed in cases of suspected ceftriaxone treatment failure for gonococcal urethritis?
7. What antibiotics should be tested? Describe the natural history of antimicrobial resistance to each of these agents.

sect1.para: N. gonorrhoeae was recovered from the patient’s culture, and susceptibility testing was performed at a regional Antimicrobial Resistance Laboratory Network (ARLN) laboratory. The isolate was resistant to ciprofloxacin but susceptible to azithromycin, cefixime, and ceftriaxone. Repeated infection was ultimately determined to be the driver behind the multiple presentations and not associated with treatment failure.

listitem.para: 8. What action is recommended to address sexual partners of patients with gonorrhea?
9. In cases of suspected child abuse or sexual assault, testing for N. gonorrhoeae may be needed. What is the recommended testing strategy, and what additional considerations are needed?
10. What is doxycycline postexposure prophylaxis (doxy PEP) and what are the benefits of this strategy?

sect1.para: 1. The patient’s presentation is consistent with urethritis. The most common infectious causes of urethritis are N. gonorrhoeae (gonococcal urethritis; GU) and C. trachomatis (non-gonococcal urethritis; NGU). Other causes of NGU include Mycoplasma genitalium, T. vaginalis, and herpes simplex virus (HSV).

2. NAATs are the recommended methods for diagnosing all the listed causes of GU and NGU due to the increased sensitivity compared to other methods, while maintaining high specificity (1). NAATs for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis are FDA approved when testing urine, endocervical, vaginal, and urethral samples. Some assays are also FDA approved for extragenital sites, including rectal and pharyngeal sources. Conjunctival swabs, used primarily in the diagnosis of congenital gonorrhea or chlamydia, are not FDA-approved sample types for NAAT testing, but some laboratories have internally validated this source as a laboratory-developed test. M. genitalium NAATs are FDA approved from urine or urethral samples, while T. vaginalis NAATs are FDA approved for all GU samples previously listed. T. vaginalis can also be tested via saline wet mount from endocervical or urethral swabs or rapid test from vaginal swabs where NAAT testing is not available. HSV NAAT is recommended from a swab of a lesion when present. In addition to these diagnostic tests for urethritis, screening for HIV is recommended for all sexually active men ages 13 to 64 years and syphilis screening is recommended for adults at increased risk, which includes males <29 years of age (2).

3. People with sexually transmitted infections (STIs) frequently do not return for follow-up care, so the administration of antimicrobials before being released from the ED (or clinic) is essential. Current CDC-recommended empiric therapy guidelines for urethritis include a single 500-mg IM injection of ceftriaxone (for gonorrhea) and 100 mg of oral doxycycline twice daily for 7 days (for chlamydia) (3). For an in-depth discussion of C. trachomatis, see case 3.

4. There are three possibilities to consider. The first is that the patient had persistent N. gonorrhoeae infection. Ceftriaxone-resistant N. gonorrhoeae isolates have been detected globally, a significant threat to the currently recommended treatment regimens. The greatest increase in such cases has been observed in the Asia-Pacific region, but detections have also occurred in other countries. However, to date CDC reports that ceftriaxone-resistant isolates have not been detected in the United States. A graphical representation of antimicrobial resistance in N. gonorrhoeae over the past century is shown in Fig. 2.1. Ceftriaxone resistance is an unlikely explanation for this patient given he received appropriate therapy and stated that symptoms resolved prior to the second presentation. The second possibility is reinfection. While the patient did not report any new sexual partners, he was not abstinent and could have acquired a new N. gonorrhoeae infection. Finally, there is the possibility of a persistent positive N. gonorrhoeae NAAT due to the detection of residual DNA from the prior infection. An important consideration for the use of NAAT testing as a test of cure or for diagnosis in close temporal proximity to a prior infection is the expected length of time that “leftover” DNA from successfully treated organisms may remain in the sample type. The most likely explanation for this patient’s positive N. gonorrhoeae NAAT and symptoms was reinfection.

figure.title: Figure 2.1 Timeline of antimicrobial resistance in N. gonorrhoeae. SUL, sulfonamides; PEN, penicillin; SPT, spectinomycin; TET, tetracycline; CIP, ciprofloxacin; OFX, ofloxacin; CFM, cefixime; CRO, ceftriaxone; AZM, azithromycin; DOX, doxycycline. Reprinted from Unemo M, Shafer WM. 2014. Clin Microbiol Rev 27:587–613.

textobject.para: A timeline chart showing the rise of antibiotic resistance in gonorrhea from the 1930s to 2020, highlighting key antibiotics used, resistance genes, and the emergence of multidrug-resistant and potentially untreatable strains.

sect1.para: 5. Following appropriate therapy, N. gonorrhoeae DNA from nonviable organisms clears from urogenital samples within about a week (4). It is recommended that subsequent testing following an infection be performed at least 2 weeks after completion of therapy. Studies looking at repeat testing for C. trachomatis found residual DNA for up to 3 weeks; therefore, at least a 1-month interval is recommended before subsequent NAAT testing (5).

6. Culture of N. gonorrhoeae and susceptibility testing are recommended for patients with suspected treatment failure. This recommendation accomplishes two goals: (i) isolation of the organism from a clinical sample eliminates the possibility of persistent detection of residual DNA by NAAT; and (ii) the possibility of treatment failure due to antimicrobial resistance can be investigated. N. gonorrhoeae is a fastidious Gram-negative, intracellular diplococcus. As such, isolation of N. gonorrhoeaerequires enriched media (e. g., chocolate agar) incubated in a 5% CO2 environment. To inhibit the growth of normal microbiota from the sampling site and enhance recovery of N. gonorrhoeae, specially designed media such as modified Thayer-Martin or GC-Lect can be used (6). N. gonorrhoeae is a labile organism, and viability can be impacted by protracted transport times between collection and plating. In such cases, a transport medium, such as Amies transport, should be considered (7). Procedures and interpretive criteria for susceptibility testing on N. gonorrhoeae are outlined in the CLSI M100 (8). Gradient diffusion testing is also available through regional public health laboratories in the CDC’s ARLN (9). Consultation with CDC experts is recommended in cases of suspected treatment failure (10).

7. Testing conducted through CDC’s ARLN includes fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin), macrolides (azithromycin), and cephalosporins (cefixime and ceftriaxone). CLSI also recommends testing tetracycline as a first-line agent.

Fluoroquinolone-resistant N. gonorrhoeae emerged in the early 2000s. In 2007, in response to rising resistance, CDC removed fluoroquinolones from the recommended therapies for N. gonorrhoeae (11). Resistance rates of 20 to 30% continue to be observed (12). Mechanisms of resistance include mutations in the gyrA and parC genes, along with mutations in the efflux pump-encoding gene mtrR (13).

Macrolide resistance, specifically azithromycin resistance, increased in surveillance data in the early 2010s to an average of 2.5%. The highest rates of resistance were seen in the Midwest. At that time, dual therapy, including a cephalosporin and azithromycin, was the regimen of choice. In 2015, citing rising rates of macrolide resistance and antimicrobial stewardship concerns, azithromycin was excluded from the recommended treatment in favor of ceftriaxone monotherapy(14). Mechanisms of resistance include mutations in the rrl gene, methylation of the 23S rRNA gene, and overexpression of efflux pumps (13).

Cefixime and ceftriaxone are both third-generation (extended-spectrum) cephalosporins. Historically, resistance to these agents was rare. In fact, CLSI interpretive criteria for both drugs only include a susceptible breakpoint (no resistant interpretation), an indication of the limited data on extended-spectrum cephalosporin-resistant N. gonorrhoeae needed to inform such interpretation. However, elevated MICs, cefixime MIC of ≥0.25 μg/ml or ceftriaxone MIC of ≥0.125 μg/ml, referred to as nonsusceptible, have been observed. Rates of nonsusceptibility observed in surveillance data are higher for cefixime, up to 1.4%, than ceftriaxone, which has remained <1% (12). In 2020, with antimicrobial stewardship in mind and a focus on preserving cephalosporin susceptibility for N. gonorrhoeae, the CDC removed cefixime from the recommended treatment options in favor of IM ceftriaxone. This rationale is in part supported by data showing that IM ceftriaxone is more active against N. gonorrhoeae with elevated MICs when compared to oral cefixime (15). Mechanisms of resistance for low-level cephalosporin nonsusceptibility include mutations in the penA gene and overexpression of efflux pumps. High-level resistance is also mediated through changes in the penA gene, although unique from those seen in low-level resistance.

For decades, tetracycline resistance in N. gonorrhoeae has been high. As of 2021, CDC’s Gonococcal Isolate Surveillance Project reported a resistance rate of ~20% (16). Resistance is both plasmid and chromosomally mediated (13).

8. CDC recommends contacting sexual partners within the preceding 60 days of the patient's infection, or most recent sexual partner if last contact was >60 days. These contacts should be offered testing and presumptive therapy in an attempt to treat unrecognized cases and prevent further transmission.

9. NAAT testing is still the recommended testing strategy in cases of suspected child abuse. Testing should be performed using FDA-approved methodologies, although no test is FDA approved for children (17). Therefore, discussion with laboratory experts is needed to ensure that testing has been rigorously validated to CLIA standards when testing samples from children (18). Every effort should be made to ensure specificity for N. gonorrhoeae in testing and avoid potential false positives with non-gonococcal Neisseria that may be part of normal microbiota. This can be accomplished by confirmatory testing using NAATs that differ in detection targets or chemistry (5). Additionally, culture and isolation of N. gonorrhoeae can be used to confirm the molecular result. Certainty in the diagnosis of gonorrhea in cases of child abuse is paramount given the social and medicolegal implications.

10. Doxy PEP is a strategy of prescribing doxycycline postexposure prophylaxis to prevent bacterial STIs. Taken within 72 hours of sexual contact, prophylactic doxycycline has been shown to dramatically reduce the number of syphilis and chlamydia infections (>70%) and gonorrhea (50%). CDC recommends offering doxy PEP to men who have sex with men and transgender women, particularly to individuals who have had a bacterial STI within the past year. STI screening and discussion around HIV preexposure prophylaxis or strategies to prevent other STIs not covered by prophylactic doxycycline should also occur.

listitem.para: N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis are the leading causes of urethritis. Other infectious causes include T. vaginalis, M. genitalium, and herpes simplex virus.
Nucleic acid amplification testing is the recommended method for diagnosing urethritis.
Empiric therapy should target both gonorrhea (500 mg of intramuscular ceftriaxone) and chlamydia (100 mg of doxycycline twice daily for 1 week) as patients are often lost to care.
Cephalosporin-resistant N. gonorrhoeae isolates, including ceftriaxone, have been recognized globally, posing a threat to first-line therapy should resistance increase.
In cases of suspected treatment failure, culture and susceptibility testing can help guide therapy. Consultation with the CDC is recommended in such cases.
Susceptibility testing can be performed locally or through the CDC ARLN. At a minimum, testing should be performed for ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, cefixime, and ceftriaxone.
Contact tracing to identify sexual partners of the infected individual should be performed. Identified sexual contacts should be offered testing and prophylactic therapy.

Testing in cases of suspected child abuse or sexual assault should be conducted using validated methods and an FDA-approved methodology. Consultation with laboratory experts is important given the sensitive and impactful nature of diagnosis.
Doxy PEP, can be offered to men who have sex with men and transgender women as a strategy to reduce bacterial STIs, including gonorrhea.
